, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tato manojavitvan\nvikarannabhavah pradhanajayashch<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sattvapurushanyatakhyatimatrasysarvabhavadhishthatritvam\nsarvajnatritvan cha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadvairajnadapi\ndoshabijakshaye kaivalyam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sthanyupanimantrane\nsanggasmayakarannanpunah anishtaprasanggat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">kshannatatkramayoh\nsanyamadavivekajam jnanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatilakshannadeshairanyataanavachchhedattulyayostatah\npratipattih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tarakan sarvavishayan\nsarvathavishayam akramancheti vivekajan jnanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sattvapurushayoh\nshuddhisamye kaivalyam iti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHAPTER IV--&nbsp; KAIVALYA PADA --&nbsp; LIBERATION<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">janmaushadhimantratapahsamadhijah\nsiddhayah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatyantaraparinamah\nprakrityapoorat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nimittam aprayojakan\nprakritinan varannabhedastutatah kshetrikavat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nirmannachittanyasmitamatrat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">pravrittibhede\nprayojakam chittam ekam anekesham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatra dhyanajam\nanashayam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">karmashuklakrishnnam\nyoginah trividham itaresham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatastadvipakanugunanam\nevabhivyaktirvasananam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatideshakalavyavahitanam\napyanantaryamsmritisanskarayoh ekaroopatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tasam anaditvam\nchashisho nityatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hetufalashrayalambanaih\nsangrihitatvad eshamabhave tadabhavah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">atitanagatan\nsvaroopatostyadhvabhedad<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">te vyaktasookshma\ngunatmanah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">parinamaikatvad\nvastutattvam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vastusamye chittabhedat\ntayorvibhaktah panthah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">taduparagapekshatvat\nchittasya vastu jnatajnatam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sada\njnatashchittavrittayastatprabhohpurushasyaparinamitvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">na tat\nsvabhasandrishyatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ekasamaye\nchobhayanavadharannam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chittantaradrishye\nbuddhibuddheratiprasanggah smritisankarashcha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chiterapratisankramayastadakarapattausvabuddhisanvedanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">drashtridrishyoparaktan\nchittan sarvartham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadasankhyeyavasanachitram\napi pararthan sanhatyakaritvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">visheshadarshin\naatmabhavabhavanavinivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada vivekanimnan\nkaivalyapragbharan chittam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tachchhidreshu\npratyayantarani sanskarebhyah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hanam esham\nkleshavaduktam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">prasankhyanepyakusidasy\nsarvathavivekakhyaterdharmameghah samadhih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah\nkleshakarmanivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada\nsarvavarannamalapetasyjnanasyaanantyajgyeyam alpam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah kritarthanan\nparinamakramapari samaptirgunanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">kshannapratiyogi\nparinamaparantanigrarhyah kramah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">purusharthashoonyanan\ngunanan pratiprasavahkaivalyan, svaroopapratishtha va chitishaktireti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.24- - tadasankhyeyavasanachitram\napi pararthan sanhatyakaritvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Though the framework of\nconsciousness is interwoven with innumerable desires and subconscious\nimpressions, it exists for the seer on account of its proximity to the seer as\nwell as to the objective world. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Though consciousness\nhas been fogged with impressions (samskaras) throughout eternity, its aim is\nnot only to satisfy the desires of the senses (bhoga), but also to further the\nemancipation (apavarga) of the soul. Consciousness is tied by a hidden force\nboth to the seer and to nature. It is well equipped to reach the seer, though\nit has no ambition of its own except to serve its Lord. Consciousness has\ninnumerable inclinations and impressions derived from memory, among which\nlonging for pleasures and freedom from pleasures stand out. They are desired impressions.\nFrom this, it becomes clear that consciousness, being close to nature and\nspirit, feels that it does not exist for its own sake but for the sake of\npurusa and prakrti.. Once consciousness is cultured through yogic discipline,\nit becomes matured and illumined. It realises that the seer is not interested\nin objects of pleasure and opts to serve with disengagement. Now that it\ncomprehends its inner value, it realises the triviality of nature's pleasures\nand turns towards the path of Self-Realisation. Thus transformed, it begins its\njourney towards emancipation. If one's karmas are good, they awaken curiosity\nand guide it towards the path of kaivalya; they reward one's effort with the\nvision of the soul. Yogic practices speed up this process, beginning with the\nconquering of the body and ending in the vision of the soul. &nbsp;This is salvation. &nbsp;For most modern scientists (who have NO access\nto the wisdom of the Vedas ) mind appears to be the master, which receives\nnumerous inputs through senses, synthesizes them and understands them. But,\nmind is not the master. It is just an efficient manager. It is always working\nfor the Purusha, the pure consciousness. The master never appears in the\nforefront. But, the power of illumination belongs to the Master. The mind\nreceives only a reflection of this power, to receive the numerous impressions\nof the world outside. One must understand the process very clearly and keep the\nmind as an efficient manager working for the self, which is the Purusha, the\npure consciousness. The Purusha may be a mere witness, the ultimate seer. He\nmay have the capability to illumine himself and illumine the mind, and through\nthe mind, the external world. But, Purusha has to operate only through the\nmind, which has no self illumining capability, for which it depends on the\nPurusha. The bridge between the Purusha and the world is the mind. That mind\nfield, though filled with countless impressions, exists for the benefit of\nanother witnessing consciousness, as the mind field is operating only in\ncombination with those impressions. However subtle we go in our exploration of\nthe depths of the mind, that mind itself gets its life force from pure\nconsciousness, like the electricity and the computer. &nbsp;&nbsp;The computer cant perform without\nelectricity. This pure consciousness is the Reality that we want to experience,\nunalloyed even by the subtlest aspect of mental process. While the computer operates\nfor the external user, it is the other way around with consciousness. The mind\nfield operates for the benefit of the consciousness. Though having countless\ndesires, the mind-stuff exists for the sake of another [the Purusha] because it\nan act only in association with it. Though the fabric of consciousness is\ninterwoven with innumerable desires and subconscious impressions, it exists for\nthe seer on account of its proximity to the seer as well as to the objective\nworld. &nbsp;This is because the mind cannot\nfunction without the power of the Perceiver. The mind is a compound of various\nthings, and therefore it cannot work for itself. &nbsp;The proximity (samhatya) of the spirit is\nitself, the cause of the innumerable moods and urges.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.25- -</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">visheshadarshin\naatmabhavabhavanavinivrittih</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">For one who realises\nthe distinction between citta and atma, the sense of separation between the two\ndisappears. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the difference\nbetween consciousness (citta) and the projector of the consciousness (citi) is\nrecognised, the search for Self-Realisation ends. &nbsp;From iv.15 to iv.25, Patanjali takes the\nsadhaka progressively to the realisation that consciousness is not the\nall-knower, but simply an instrument of the soul. &nbsp;For one who is not sure of the difference\nbetween consciousness and soul (citta and citi), an analogy is given; the\nblades of grass which shoot up during the rainy season prove the existence of\nthe hidden seeds. &nbsp;In this sutra\nPatanjali explains that the seed of the soul (atma bija) is sown at the right\ntime for the knowledge of the soul (atma jnana) to be securely established. As\none mistakes a rope for a snake at first glance, but realises upon examination\nthat it is a rope, consciousness at this stage realises that it is not\nall-knowing, but an instrument of the soul. Avidya is vanquished and the\npractitioner thoroughly understands objective as well as subjective knowledge,\nwithout colourisation. Here all moods and modes cease to flow, and\nconsciousness is elevated to the optimum degree to behold the inebriated state\nof the seer. The yogi is no longer drawn towards the temptations of the world.\nHis search for the self ends. He becomes a master of yoga and a master of\nhimself. He is yogesvara. This is the substance (svarupa) of yoga and a\ndistinct attribute of the seer (visesa darsinah). For one who has experienced\nthis distinction between seer and this subtlest mind, the false identities and\neven the curiosity about the nature of one's own self come to an end. After the\nyogi has explored the many currents and cross currents of the gross and subtle\nmind, there comes the realization of the separateness from all of these levels\nand pure consciousness. It is then, that all of these questions cease. It is\nnot a case that they are analytically answered in logical words. Rather, the\nquestions are resolved; they simply evaporate in understanding. Patanjali is\nnow explaining the nature of that yogi who has realized the distinction between\nthe seer, the seen and the mind very clearly. In other words, he is now the\nviveki, the one proficient in discriminating faculty; the one who can perceive\nthe truth and differentiate it from the one which is not \u2013 easily. At this\nstage, the mind also is the purest possible reflector of external reality,\nwithout any coloring either on itself&nbsp; or\non the scenery.&nbsp; The seer, the Purusha,\nthe pure consciousness knows this. He has experienced the external reality in\nits purest form, since no coloring affects it now. There are now no false\nidentities. &nbsp;There is not even any\nfurther curiosity about the nature of one's own self. There is complete\ncessation of all doubt between the seer, the seen and the nature of mind. There\nis a complete cessation of any desire, including the desire to reside in the\nPurusha. The pure mind has come close to the Purusha and is accepting his\nMastery. To one who sees the distinction between the mind and the Atman,\nthoughts of mind as the Atman cease forever. For one who realizes the\ndistinction between citta and atma, the sense of separation between the two\ndisappears. The man of discrimination ceases to regard the mind as the Atman. For\none who has experienced this distinction between seer and this subtlest mind,\nthe false identities and even the curiosity about the nature of one's own self\ncome to an end.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.26- - tada\nvivekanimnan kaivalyapragbharan chittam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Then consciousness is\ndrawn strongly towards the seer or the soul due to the influence &nbsp;of the exalted intelligence. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the exalted\nintelligence is ablaze, consciousness is illumined; it becomes free and tinged\nwith the divine (citta suddhi). Due to this divine light, citta, with its\nexalted intelligence, is attracted as if by a magnet towards its source - the\nindivisible seer who is alone, free and full. Before reaching the state of\nexalted intelligence, consciousness is attracted more towards the pleasures of\nthe world. When intelligence is free from doubts and prejudices, it gravitates\ntowards the absolute seer. As a farmer builds dykes between his fields to\nregulate the flow of water, similarly, exalted intelligence builds a dyke for\nthe consciousness, so that it does not move again towards the world, but turns\nand flows towards union with the divine seer. This is kaivalya, an existence\nfilled with freedom and beatitude. Such a yogi becomes a king amongst men. Viveka\nmeans clear discrimination between Truth and what is not truth. Truth liberates\nfrom ignorance, while what is not truth binds the sadhaka to Ignorance. The\nmind-field is always looking outward through the senses and its perception is\nalways coloured. But, once the coloring is removed, the mind-field, the Chitta\nalso becomes a clear, pure receiver of external wisdom because of the\nilluminating power that it has received from the Purusha. &nbsp;Now, mind is inclined towards clear viveka or\ndiscrimination faculty in its power of perception and therefore, the ignorance\nbinding it, comes down and down and tends to remove the veil of ignorance from\nthe Purusha. Purusha is now shining clearly. Mind also therefore gravitates\ntowards total liberation. What is the liberation? It is nothing but the\ndropping of all barriers to wisdom, the barriers to truth that had arisen in\nmind due to the covering of Ignorance. What is the ignorance of the mind-field?\nIt is its identification with the body-mind complex. Once the self realizes\nthat it is not the body-mind complex, the barriers covering the mind-field drop\naway easily. The mind-field should detach from the drisya and become and\nefficient aid of the real Master, the Prabhu, the Purusha, the self, the\nconsciousness. Now, all barriers drop off. Discrimination, viveka comes home\nautomatically. Renunciation, vairagya and liberation happen effortlessly,\neffectively and automatically. Then the mind is inclined towards the highest\ndiscrimination, and gravitates towards absolute liberation between seer and\nseen. When even the subtlest questions of life subside, there is only one\ndirection left to go, and that is towards the realization of the absolute\nreality that is beyond. This is not a case of a lethargic mind having no\nquestion about the meaning of life; such a mind has not even entered the path\nof Self-realization. Rather, it comes from having questioned, explored,\nsearched, and longed, through the gross, subtle, and causal levels, until\nfinally, the point of the final discrimination stands in front of the seeker. When\nthe mind is bent on the practice of discrimination, it moves toward liberation.\nAnd their clarity takes them to their only concern; to reach and remain in a\nstate of freedom.&nbsp; The yogi has to\nachieve this.&nbsp; It does not come by\nwishful thinking.&nbsp; Only through higher\nyoga can this be achieved consistently. Practice of Yoga leads to\ndiscriminating power, to clearness of vision. The veil drops from the eyes, and\nwe see things as they are. &nbsp;When\ndiscrimination comes by long practice fear ceases, and the mind attains\nisolation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.27- - tachchhidreshu\npratyayantarani sanskarebhyah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Notwithstanding this\nprogress, if one is careless during the interval, a fissure arises due to past\nhidden impressions, creating division between the consciousness and the seer. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The force of past\nimpressions may create loopholes in the form of intellectual pride or other\nvarying moods or modes of thought, which breach the consciousness and agitate\nthe harmony and serenity of oneness with the pure Self (atmabhava). This sutra\nshows a way to fight old impressions that may influence the consciousness and\ncrack it. Patanjali cautions that even for the supreme intelligence, the\nsubconscious samskaras may surface in this intermediate stage and sway the\nconsciousness. Patanjali advises yogis who wish to be released from worldly\nlife to be incessantly vigilant in order to overcome these old habits, lest\ntheir consciousness wavers between the desire for perfection and actual\nperfection. The uninterrupted practice of yoga unconditionally crushes these\nfissures in consciousness, and eliminates doubts and prejudices, so that pure\nwisdom may shine. In the Bhagavad Gita 11.59, Lord Krishna says that inbuilt\ndesire persists as a fissure even in the most austere renunciate. Only the\nvision of the Supreme resolves these latent faults forever. From that moment no\nworldly desire or temptation can endanger the composure and virtue of the yogi .Patanjali\nsays, even at this point, there will be some very deep impressions, very deeply\ningrained Samskaras, which rise again and again to pull down the viveka and put\nbarriers in its path. This happens many times. This is because, some of these\ndeepest, ingrained samskaras&nbsp; take time\nand effort to be totally rooted out. The same methods already gone through for\nremoval of samskaras must be continued to be adopted&nbsp; till the last remnants are rooted out. For\nthis, retaining a high level of awareness of them is however essential. When\nthere are breaks or breaches in that high discrimination, other impressions\narise from the deep unconscious. The clarity of discrimination can once again\nbe clouded over. This temporary loss of the ground attained is one of the\npredictable obstacles of the path of enlightenment. The way to deal with this\nis the same as it was before the discriminative enlightenment . In the\nrelaxation of the focus, other mind contents arise in the intervals.&nbsp; These are based on subtle impressions. The\nyogi faces failures at every step but he must forge ahead.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.28- -</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">hanam\nesham kleshavaduktam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">In the same way as the\nsadhaka strives to be free from afflictions, the yogi must handle these latent\nimpressions judiciously to extinguish them. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The gap between\nconsciousness and the seer can rear disharmony and disturbance in one's self.\nAs fire is deprived of fuel, likewise, the yogi has to remove the latent\nimpressions from the consciousness and extinguish them, for it to be in harmony\nwith the seer. Patanjali advises the yogi to eliminate disturbances by\nreintroducing yogic disciplines with faith, vigour and vitality. As the sadhaka\nearlier strove to rid himself of the sufferings of avidya, asmita, raga, dvesa\nand abhinivesa, the exalted yogi must, through practice, press, dry out and\nclose the perforations in the consciousness. iv. 27 stated that subconscious\nimpressions surface in the form of intellectual pride, which hinders progress\ntowards the goal of union with the divine seer. As roasted seeds do not\ngerminate, so the fire of wisdom must burn out impressions and ambitions,\nending their power to generate disturbing thoughts, so that the consciousness\nmaintains its union with the seer forever. Patanjali has taught us all the\nmethods for removal and rooting out of kleshas like ignorance and suffering\nthroughout the Yoga Sutras earlier. The removal of the remaining kleshas also\nneeds to be done by the same methods. &nbsp;First,\nyou seek enough purity of mind and body that you can experience the highest.\nThen, after that direct experience, the way in which you relate to samskaras\nand karma is vastly different. You have glimpsed the highest, and knowing that,\nthe purifying process. One must never accommodate even small errors because\nthey are as detrimental as the five obstacles.&nbsp;\nEach yogi has to endure and overcome this inner conflict alone.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.29- - prasankhyanepyakusidasy\nsarvathavivekakhyater dharmameghah samadhih</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The yogi who has no\ninterest even in this highest state of evolution, and maintains supreme\nattentive,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"line-height: 24px;\">discriminating</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;awareness, attains dharmameghah samadhi. &nbsp; He\ncontemplates the fragrance of virtue and justice. <o:p></o:p></span></span></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the stream of\nvirtue pours in torrents and the consciousness is washed clean of bias,\nprejudice and ambition, the light of the soul dawns. This is dharma megha\nsamadhi - the fruit of the practice of yoga. &nbsp;If the yogi, knowing that the highest form of\nintelligence is also a hindrance, remains uninterested even in this enlightened\nwisdom as well as in spiritual attainments, virtuousness descends upon him like\ntorrential rain, washing away his individual personality. His only ambition now\nis to sustain spiritual health. He has purity and clarity. His personality has\nbeen transformed. He becomes humane, universal and divine. He lives forever in\ndharma megha samadhi, unexcelled bliss. &nbsp;A\ncloud has two facets. It may cover the sky without bringing rain. This makes\nthe atmosphere gloomy and people become inactive and dull. But if the cloud\nbursts into rain, the atmosphere is cleared, the sun shines, and people go out\nto work gleefully. The yogi should not make the consciousness quiet in a tamasic\nway, but in an alert, satvic way to shine forth brilliantly to live in the\ndelightful, fragrant rain-cloud of virtue. &nbsp;He has renounced everything, and is a viveki\n(one who distinguishes the invisible soul from the visible world), ajnanin\n(sage), a vairagin (renunciate), and a bhaktan (divine devotee). Now he has\nattained nirbija Samadhi.&nbsp; Omniscience or\ntotal knowledge is what man seeks to attain as the highest state possible for\nhim. But, for yogi, even this omniscient state holds no interest at all. He\ndoes not hanker for it, nor does he feel proud when he knows he has it.\nThereby, the yogi exhibits the highest possible state of discrimination. The\nSamadhi which he is in, in&nbsp; this state is\ncalled Dharma Megha Samadhi, or the Samadhi of the cloud of virtue. This renouncement\nof the exalted state of omniscience is called paravairagya or the ultimate\nrenunciation. One can renounce all desires \u2013 and go on desiring for moksha.\nBut, one can renounce even this desire for moksha. This is the state of\nabsolute desirelessness. No desires what so ever \u2013 no desire even for Moksha.\nThe desire for Moksha, or liberation is the ultimate desire and even this\ndesire is renounced to make desirelessness complete.&nbsp; This state is the state of the ultimate\ndiscrimination. And the yogi will now be in this state forever. Patanjali calls\nthis state as Dharma Megha Samadhi. Dharma means virtues, megha means clouds;\nSamadhi means the still, flickerless state at the end of dharana and dhyana. This\ndharma megha is going to remain flickerless and still with the yogi.&nbsp; Dharma means virtues. All virtues have\ndescended on the Yogi like a cloud from the sky. And, they will now remain\nstill and flickerless with the Yogi. Why is this Samadhi called a cloud? This\ncloud also covers the vision of the Yogi from the clear sky of kaivalya. &nbsp;Even\nif it is of virtues, it still covers the essential kaivalya, his total\nliberation, from the Yogi. So, to that extent, this too remains as the last\nbarrier that the yogi must come out of. When there is no longer any interest\neven in omniscience, that discrimination allows the samadhi, which brings an\nabundance of virtues like a rain cloud brings rain. : There finally comes a\npoint where discrimination has so thoroughly set aside all which is not Self\nthat even the interest in omniscience is seen as only relatively real and not\nworthy of pursuit. Then comes the highest virtues: From that non-attachment to\nomniscience there comes the samadhi that brings an abundance of virtues like a\nrain cloud brings rain. The Self may have been glimpsed before, but the\ncolorings of the deep impressions were still there. Now even those have been\ntranscended. Peace, bliss, &nbsp;and perfect\npurity becomes a yogi\u2019s &nbsp;own nature,\nafter he has&nbsp; given up all &nbsp;vanities of powers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.30- - tatah\nkleshakarmanivrittih</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Then comes the end of\nafflictions and of karma. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The effect of dharma\nmegha samadhi is freedom, freedom from the five afflictions and fluctuations.\nIt is the highest form of intelligence and evolution. From this rain-cloud of\nvirtue, sufferings cease of their own accord and in their place, divine actions\nwith no reactions flow forth like a river from the yogi. This is freedom. Avidya,\nthe mother of afflictions, is eliminated, root and branch, along with residual\nsubliminal impressions. The sadhaka will not deviate from the path of divinity\nnor perform an act that binds, hinders or preconditions his consciousness. He\nis free from the bondage of karma. In the Bhagavad Gita (V 1.5), Lord Krishna\nsays that each individual has to cultivate himself to become enlightened, and\nto learn not to degrade himself, for the Self alone is the friend of the\nindividual self, and the Self alone is the enemy of the egotistical self. As\nthe light of a lamp fades as the oil runs out, so the lamp of the mind is\nextinguished as its fuel, the actions producing joys and sorrows, is exhausted.\nAs nirmana citta is extinguished of its own accord, its root motivation is\nburnt out, leaving no opportunity for the production of effects The cycle of\ncause and effect is at an end, and the yogi is liberated from the grip of nature.\nEven in this liberated state, he will not relinquish his practices. He will\ncontinue to maintain them as a divine command, so that the freedom earned may\nnot be lost by neglect. Patanjali says \u2013 if the yogi goes beyond even this\nbarrier of virtuous cloud or Dharma megha, then, all the deepest impressions or\nsamskaras in him dissolve totally and all the kleshas or sorrows, pains and\nafflictions cease totally and absolutely. Dharma megha Samadhi is thus the last\nbarrier to cross for the successful yogi.After that dharma-meghah samadhi, the\ncolorings of the kleshas and the karmas are removed. Burning the seeds of\nkarma: This is the final dealing with the colorings (kleshas). First, the mind\nwas stabilized . Then these colorings were reduced in their gross form , then\nthey were dealt with in their subtle forms. These kleshas (colorings) moved\nthrough four stages of active, separated, attenuated, and then were reduced to\nseed form. Now, those seeds are parched, so as to not be able to grow again. First,\nthere were glimpses of Truth, which had the effect of negating the obstacles .\nAfter a great deal of sadhana (spiritual practices), there came a temporary\ndiscriminative enlightenment that was accompanied by breaches . Now, with the\nneutralizing of the colorings of the samskaras that cause karma, the\nrealization is finally firm of ground. The yogi rests in the True nature of the\nSelf . From that samadhi all afflictions and karmas cease. After that\ndharma-meghah samadhi, the colorings of the kleshas and the karmas are removed.\nFrom that comes cessation of pains and works. When that cloud of virtue has\ncome, then no more is there fear of falling, nothing can drag the Yogi down. No\nmore will there be evils for him. No more pains &nbsp;When the yogi reaches the causal level and\nsees the various clouds of energy (meghah) in which the dharmas or laws for\nrighteous life, are created and maintained, he gets an ease in his higher yoga\npractice.&nbsp; He smiles for he will never\nagain fall into the trap of making spiritual missions to help or to save others<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.31- -</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">tada\nsarvavarannamalapetasy jnanasyaanantyajgyeyam alpam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Then, when the veils of\nimpurities are removed, the highest, subjective, pure, infinite knowledge is\nattained, and the knowable, the finite, appears as trivial. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The stream of virtue\nextinguishes all the veils of impurities. The yogi is devoid of doubts,\npreconceptions and prejudices. The infinite light of the soul illumines him\ncontinuously, and his consciousness and the seer become one. For him, knowledge\ngained through the organs of cognition and through consciousness are\ninsignificant compared with the infinite wisdom emanating from the soul. This\nsutra describes the characteristics of the yogi who is devoid of afflicting\nactions. His head becomes clear and his heart clean and pure as crystal. When\nthe clouds dissipate, the sky becomes clear. When the sun is bright, no other\nlight is required. When the light of the soul blazes, the yogi does not need\nmind or intelligence to develop knowledge. . In this sutra, as the\nconsciousness has been fully matured, he cautions the yogi that if fissures are\nformed in the cttta, afflictions will affect him instantaneously and not at a\nfuture time. His knowledge springs eternally from the seed of all knowledge\n(atman) and jnana gahga (perennial river of wisdom), and he perceives directly.\nThe cover that has clouded the Jnanam is now totally removed. It is shining in\nits pristine purity and totality now.&nbsp;\nThe Jneyam, the thing to be known is now almost nothing. Or alpam. In\nthis state, the Purusha starts functioning by himself, and mind merely remains\nwithout clouding his experience and vision. Purusha sees and experiences the\nreality totally. There are no barriers whatsoever for him now. It can also be\nsaid, he is now the reality himself. Then all the coverings and impurities of\nknowledge are totally removed. Because of the infinity of this knowledge, what\nremains to be known is almost nothing. The, when the veils of impurities are\nremoved, the highest, subjective, pure, infinite knowledge is attained, and the\nknowable, the finite, appears as trivial. Then the whole universe, with all its\nobjects of sense-knowledge, becomes as nothing in comparison to that infinite\nknowledge which is free from all obstructions and impurities. When the mind is\nfree from the clouds that prevent perception, all is known, there is nothing to\nbe known. &nbsp;When those veils are only\ntemporarily removed or set aside, the process of purifying continues, recalling\nthat instructions were even given on how to deal with breaches in enlightenment\n.&nbsp; First comes the direct experience of\nthe infinite. It might be only a glimpse, but even that glimpse may\nqualitatively reveal the height of Truth . Then comes knowledge: One of the\nresults of that direct experience is the knowledge of the simplicity of things,\nthat there really is little to know. Then keep purifying: After that\nrealization, we then continue with renewed conviction the process of removing\nkarma, etc. Karma is removed: Finally, all karma is removed through the coming\nof the rain cloud of virtues described in the previous sutra. &nbsp;The realization that there is little to know\nis deliciously amusing, amazing, wonderful, and filled with joy. &nbsp;These insights come because of seeing the\nnature of the gunas , the way the subtle mind operates, and realizing the\nhigher discrimination. Then knowledge, bereft of covering and impurities, becoming\ninfinite, the knowable becomes small.&nbsp; Knowledge\nitself is there; its covering is gone.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.32- - tatah\nkritarthanan parinamakramapari samaptirgunanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When dharma megha\nsamadhi is attained, qualities of nature (gunas) come to rest. Having fulfilled\ntheir purpose, their sequence of successive mutations is at an end. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Having transformed the\nyogi's consciousness by the radiation of the rays of the soul, the orderly\nmutations and rhythmic sequences of the qualities of nature, sattva, rajas and\ntamas come to an end. Their tasks are fulfilled, and they return to nature. The\nessence of intelligence and the essence of consciousness both now retire to\nrest in the abode of the soul. The master, the seer or the soul, is\nindependent. He keeps the gunas in suspension, or uses them when necessary.\nThey enthusiastically serve him as committed servants, without influencing him\nas before, and without interfering in his true glory. Now the three primary\ngunas have totally fulfilled their purpose for him. They are no more needed for\nthe enlightened yogi. He has transcended all their use. Ordinarily, the three\nGunas are the ones, which go on creating an ordered sequence of events for the\nsadhaka, which he has to go through all his life. &nbsp;Now, the Yogi has transcended that ordered\nsequence of events and transformations. There is no more need for them in his\nlife. He is beyond all the three Gunas. Therefore, having fulfilled their part\nin his life, the gunas recede back into the essence from which they have come.\nThey, which means, the world of three Gunas, no more undergoes any transformation\nin the experience of the enlightened Yogi. The Purusha had jumped from the\nDivine into the world of prakruthi. There he learnt all the lessons that\nprakruthi had to offer; He was covered by the Maya, of the three Gunas, which\nwere constantly transforming his world. But, as yogi, he began coming out from\none barrier after another, set for him by the Maya. The ultimate barrier of\ndharma megha also having been transcended, the Purusha is back into the divine.\nThe whole prakruthi of the three Gunas, cannot any more, set any barriers for\nhim.&nbsp; He is now a muktha Purusha. Also\nresulting from that dharma-meghah samadhi, the three primary elements or gunas &nbsp;will have fulfilled their purpose, cease to\ntransform into further transformations, and recede back into their essence. The\ninterplay of the three gunas were earlier seen to be the cause for pain , and\nsadhana was done so as to discard this pain before it comes. The coming of the\ndharma-meghah samadhi also brings to an end the need for the three subtle\ntransitions previously discussed . Thus, the subtle material nature, having\nfulfilled its purpose, its progressive alterations end. When dharmameghah\nsamadhi is attained, qualities of nature (gunas) come to rest. Having fulfilled\ntheir purpose, their sequence of successive mutations is at an end. The three\nbasic qualities cease to follow the sequence of alternating pain and pleasure.&nbsp; Resulting from that dharma-meghah samadhi ,\nthe three primary elements or gunas &nbsp;will\nhave fulfilled their purpose, cease to transform into further transformations,\nand recede back into their essence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.33- - kshannapratiyogi\nparinamaparantanigrarhyah kramah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">As the mutations of the\ngunas cease to function, time, the uninterrupted movement of moments, stops.\nThis deconstruction of the flow of time is comprehensible only at this final\nstage of emancipation. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sequence of time is\nrelated to the order of movements of the gunas of nature. Only the yogi\nrecognises this inter-relationship and is free from gunas. The uninterrupted\nsuccession of moments is called time. These movements of moments and the\nuninterrupted mutation of the gunas of nature are distinctly recognisable at\nthe culminating point of transformation. The average person is not aware of\nmoments - he understands their movement as past, present and future. When\nmoments sup away from one's awareness, one lives in movements. Memory begins to\nexert its influence, and consciousness is felt at this juncture in the\nmovements of time. The perfect yogi lives in the moment without getting\ninvolved in movements - the movements of moments are arrested, and\npsychological and chronological time comes to an end. Living in the moment, the\nyogi sees the seer. This is evolution. Nature eternally helps the intelligence\nand consciousness towards evolution (parinama nityan), whereas the seer remains\neternally changeless (kutastha nityan). Evolution takes place in a moment.\nMoment implies instant while movement implies time. When change comes, it\narrives at once in a moment, only after a series of efforts involving movements\nof time. Transformation does not come without effort. As change is noticeable\nto an average individual, so the end transformation is distinguishable to a\nyogi by virtue of his pure wisdom - dharma megha samadhi. He is free from time,\nplace and space, while others remain trammeled in this net. He is neither\nattracted towards nature nor disturbed by it. He is now a divine yogi. Every\nchange is clearly perceived only at the end of the transformation process. Not,\nwhen the change was happening from moment to moment. It is true that each\nmoment presents a point of change in any ordered sequence of changes. But, the\nperception of the change is really clear, only when the sequence ends. All the\nthree Gunas need to undergo the full change&nbsp;\n- and then, the full change becomes comprehensible. This implies two\nthings. (1) Every moment a part of the total change is taking place. But, in\nthat moment, the change is not comprehensible. (2) At some point, a total\nchange has been completed \u2013 and it becomes perceptible and comprehensible. For\nthe Yogi, the three Gunas have stopped their transformation process. This\nmeans, the total change is visible, experience-able, and knowable for the Yogi.\nBut, the same has not happened for all others. For all others, the change\ncontinues; the transformation continues; and every moment, there is change;\nthey are not able to see the change that will come tomorrow. But, not so, for\nthe yogi who has gone beyond the dharma megha Samadhi. For him, there is no\nfurther transformation, which is hidden from him.&nbsp; All changes are known to him. The sequencing\nprocess of moments and impressions corresponds to the moments of time, and is\napprehended at the end point of the sequence. Here, in this sutra, time is\nbeing described as the uninterrupted sequence or order of the many impressions\nin the field of mind. It is this sequencing that brings the appearance of time.\nThink of a reel of movie film. You can hold it, and all of the frames in your\nhand, at one moment of time, and yet, when you play the movie through a\nprojector, you create the appearance of time. It is because of the sequencing\nof the frames, one after the other, that there appears to be time. The\n\"Aha!\" moment of understanding a sequence of moments, impressions, or\nframes comes at the end of the sequence. Recall that great emphasis is placed\non these transition moments in sutras. When you can see these moments at the\nend of the sequence, you come to understand the transformation process itself,\nand can see beyond the avidya or ignorance that veils the true self. &nbsp;Break the pattern of sequencing to transcend\ntime: Most of the time, we are caught up in time, identified with those thought\npatterns, whether gross or subtle in nature. Now, in these last few sutras, all\nof those patterns have been reduced to their primal reality, that of the three\ngunas. If you break the identity with the patterns, and the sequencing process,\nthen you break the process of time, space, and causation. The process, of which\nmoments are a counterpart, and which causes the alterations, comes to an end\nand is clearly perceived.The advanced yogi alone achieves this.&nbsp; This is an individual accomplishment, where\nthe yogi sees the moments, which in sequence make up time which is itself the\nchanging mundane energy (gunanam).&nbsp; The\nyogi clearly perceives this from afar.&nbsp;\nWhat hypnotizes other and keeps them under its control subjectively and\nobjectively, is looked upon by the yogin, just as the God would normally see\nit.As the mutations of the gunas cease to function, time, the uninterrupted\nmovement of moments, stops. This deconstruction of the flow of tie is\ncomprehensible only at this final stage of emancipation. This is the sequence of\nthe mutations which take place at every moment, but which are only perceived at\nthe end of a series.&nbsp; A sequence is the\nreplacement of one characteristic by one that follows it. This is linked to\nmoment. A replacement of characteristics is also the basis of moment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.34- --</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">purusharthashoonyanan\ngunanan pratiprasavah kaivalyan, svaroopapratishtha va chitishaktireti<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kaivalya, liberation,\ncomes when the yogi has fulfilled the purusarthas, the fourfold aims of life,\nand has transcended the gunas. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The yogi with the\nstream of virtuous knowledge is devoid of all aims of life as he is free from\nthe qualities of nature. Purusarthas are man's four aims in life - dharma\n(science of duty), artha (purpose and means of life), kama (enjoyments of life)\nand moksa (freedom from worldly pleasures). They leave the fulfilled seer and\nfuse in nature. &nbsp;Patanjali speaks of the\npurusarthas only in the very last sutra. His thoughts on the purusarthas are\nimplicitly contained in the earlier chapters, and expressed clearly at the end.\nThus, the four padas are, consciously or unconsciously, founded on these four\naims and stages of activity. &nbsp;Dharma is\nthe careful observation of one's ethical, social, intellectual and religious\nduties in daily Life. Strictly stating, this is taught at the level of\nstudentship, but it must be followed throughout life; without this religious\nquality in daily life, spiritual attainment is not possible. &nbsp;Artha is acquisition of wealth in order to\nprogress towards higher pursuits of life including understanding the main\npurpose of life. If one does not earn one's own way, dependence on another will\nlead to a parasitic life. One should never be greedy while accumulating wealth,\nbut only to meet one's needs, so that one's body is kept nurtured and one may\nbe free from worries and anxieties. In this stage one also finds a partner with\nwhom to lead a householder's life. One comes to understand human love through\nindividual friendship and compassion, so that one may later develop a universal\nfellowship leading to the realisation of divine love. The householder is\nexpected to satisfy his responsibilities of bringing up his children and\nhelping his fellow men. Thus, married life has never been considered a\nhindrance to happiness, to divine love or to the union with the Supreme Soul. &nbsp;Kama means enjoyment of the pleasures of life,\nprovided one does not lose physical health, or harmony and balance of mind. The\nSelf cannot be experienced by a weakling, and the body, the temple of the soul,\nhas to be treated with care and respect. Asana, pranayama and dhyana,\ntherefore, are essential to purify the body, stabilise the mind and clarify the\nintelligence. One must learn to use the body as a bow, and asana, pranayama and\ndhyana as arrows to be aimed at the target - the seer or the soul. Moksa means\nliberation, freedom from the bondage of worldly pleasures. It is the experience\nof emancipation and beatitude, possible only when one is free from physical,\npsychological, intellectual and environmental afflictions , and from poverty,\nignorance and pride. In this state one realises that power, knowledge, wealth\nand pleasure are merely passing phases. Each individual has to work hard to\nfree himself from the qualities of nature (gunas) in order to master them and\nbecome a gunahtan. This is the very essence of life, a state of indivisible,\ninfinite, full, unalloyed bliss. These aims involve virtuous actions and are\nlinked with the qualities of nature and the growth of consciousness. When the\ngoal of freedom is attained, the restricting qualities of consciousness and\nnature cease to exist. At this point of fulfilment, the yogi realises that the\nseeker, the seer and the instrument used to cognise the seer is atman. This\nabsoluteness of consciousness is nothing but the seer. Now, he is established\nin his own nature. This is kaivalyavastha. &nbsp;The practice of yoga serves every aim of life.\nThrough the proper use of the organs of action, senses of perception, mind,\nego, intelligence and consciousness, their purpose of serving their Lord, the\nseer, comes to an end, and these vestments of the seer, along with the\nqualities of nature, coil and withdraw, to unite in the root of nature (mula-prakrti).\n&nbsp;There, they are held and isolated. By\nthis, the citta becomes pure and supreme. In this supreme state, citta divinely\nmerges in the abode of the seer so that the seer can shine forth in his\nimmaculate, pure and untarnished state of aloneness. Now, the yogi shines as a\nking amongst men. He is crowned with spiritual wisdom. He is a krtarthan - a\nfulfilled soul, who has learned to control the property of nature. He brings\npurity of intelligence into himself. He is now free from the rhythmic mutation\nof gunas, of time, and thus released from aims and objects, as his search for\nthe soul ends. All the twenty-four principles of nature move back into nature\nand the twenty-fifth, the seer, stands alone, in kaivalyam. He is one without a\nsecond; he lives in benevolent freedom and beatitude. With this power of pure\nconsciousness, citta shakti, he surrenders completely to the seed of all seers,\nParamatma or God. Lord Krishna, in the Bhagavad Gita (XVIII.6I-62), explains\nthat 'the Supreme Ruler abides in the hearts of all beings and guides them,\nmounting them on wheels of knowledge should seek refuge by surrendering all\nactions as well as himself to the Supreme Spirit or God' so that he journeys\nfrom Self-Realisation towards God-Realisation. &nbsp;Patanjali began the journey towards the\nspiritual kingdom with the word atha, meaning 'now'. He ends with the word iti,\nmeaning 'that is all'. The yogi has reached his goal.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The whole drama of the\nworld goes on due to the emergence of the three gunas (or prakruti) as the\ncoverage or aavarana around the Purusha \u2013 making him dance with the mind-field\nand its vrittis. Now, they have resolved back into their original form into the\nprakriti, leaving the Purusha free from the covering, or from the barriers\ncreated by them. The Chitta vrittis were the barriers. Purusha has scored a\ntotal victory over them now. Therefore, the three Gunas resolve back to their\noriginal position in the Prakriti. The yogi has conquered the chitta vrittis\ncompletely. He is now liberated from all of them, totally. He has emerged\nenlightened . He is now established in his original nature. This is kaivalya. When\nthose primary elements involve, or resolve themselves back into that out of\nwhich they emerged, there comes liberation, wherein the power of pure\nconsciousness becomes established in its true nature. When those primary\nelements or gunas involve, or resolve themselves back into that out of which\nthey emerged, there comes liberation, wherein the power of pure consciousness\n(purusha) becomes established in its true nature . Such an enlightened Yogi is\npurely spontaneous, with no actions whatsoever being motivated by the inner\ndrives of samskaras and karma. One hundred percent of actions are from the\nhere-and-now response to the needs of the moment, in relation to the service of\nother beings. This is easy for such a yogi, as there is no I and no other; it\nis all a constant flow of pure, undivided consciousness (purusha), that only\nseems to play, here, there, and everywhere. Kaivala, liberation, comes when the\nyogi has fulfilled the purusarthas, the fourfold aims of life, and has\ntranscended the gunas. Aims and gunas return to their source, and consciousness\nis established in its own natural purity. Since the gunas no longer have any\npurpose to serve for the Atman, they resolve themselves into Prakriti. This is\nliberation. The Atman shines forth in its own pristine nature, as pure\nconsciousness. When the highest purpose of life is achieved the three basic\nqualities do not excite responses in the mind. That is freedom. In other words,\nthe Perceiver is no longer colored by the mind. When those primary elements\ninvolve, or resolve themselves back into that out of which they emerged, there\ncomes liberation, wherein the power of pure consciousness becomes established\nin its true nature.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here ends the exposition of kaivalya, the fourth pada of\nPatanjali's Yoga Sutras. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali Maharishi covered everything in the mystic\npractice of yoga.&nbsp; All glories unto\nhim.&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-gWCH8DVUqX4/V7VfgGTnbfI/AAAAAAABLWM/PIu4FjEj8ysMlTjgpeqjsiNtWHVtCpY5ACLcB/s1600/praQna2.gif\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-gWCH8DVUqX4/V7VfgGTnbfI/AAAAAAABLWM/PIu4FjEj8ysMlTjgpeqjsiNtWHVtCpY5ACLcB/s640/praQna2.gif\" width=\"422\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c4781509413265137729\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_40M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px;
