Because, all thinking essentially relates you to either the\npast or the future but not to the reality of the present. Even the future is\nnothing but a projection of all past experiences into the future. Nothing\nexists in the future without a basis from the past. If past is got rid of,\nfuture also dissolves, because, it loses all of its past base. If both the past\nand the future lose their appeal for the mind and dissolve from its attention \u2013\nthen the present arises forcefully, beautifully like an eternity in itself. In\nthe present, all desires vanish. We need to recognize that all desires\nessentially pertain to future. They neither pertain to past nor to the present.\nWhen the meditation is only on the present \u2013 mind-field becomes totally devoid\nof any karma. It will be the original one you got at birth; it will be devoid\nof desires. All meditation must be done in a very, relaxed, playful way,\nbecause, all seriousness relates to and comes along with the past. Leave all\nseriousness. Keep playful, pleasant and unburdened by past and future. Then,\nMeditation becomes real and easy. Then, Meditation frees the Mind from any of\nthe remaining desires in it easily. &nbsp;The\nthing to cultivate is the mind of a meditator, which is free from stored\nimpressions and the play of karma. Influence on another by one whose mind is in\na state of dhyana can never increase anxiety or other obstacles. In fact, they\nare reduced. Until a yogi gets clarity of consciousness he cannot transcend his\nfeelings.&nbsp;&nbsp; He is continually fooled by\nthem.&nbsp; When he masters the effortless\nlinkage of the mind to higher realities, then he gains objectively and can sort\nout the endearing but harmful feelings, even the memory which is a storehouse\nof these.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">4.07---</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">karmashuklakrishnnam\nyoginah trividham itaresham</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">A yogi's actions are\nneither white nor black. The actions of others are of three kinds - white,\nblack or grey. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This sutra speaks of\nthree types of actions and their effects on an average individual, but there\nare in fact four. The fourth is free, uncoloured and pure. The yogi follows\nthis kind of action to be free from its fruits. The unmixed actions of the yogi\nare beyond sattva, rajas and tamas. They yield no positive or negative\nreactions in consciousness and hence are free from duality. This fourth type of\naction is propitious and auspicious. This is the real 'skill in action' of the\nyogi .An average person is saturated with ambitious thoughts. He desires\nrewards for his deeds, but forgets that they carry the seeds of pain. If his\nambition is transformed into spiritual aspiration, he loses interest in rewards\nand comes to understand sadhana for the sake of sadhana, or action for the sake\nof action. He becomes refined; his mind and consciousness become clear and his\nactions clean. He collects no impressions. He takes future births only to\ncleanse himself of past-accumulated impressions. He anchors his mind and\nconsciousness unreservedly to the will of the divine. All his actions are free\nfrom the seeds of reactions. Of all discussions on how to belong to the world,\nact in it and yet remain unsullied; pride of place is often given to the debate\nbetween Lord Krishna and Arjuna on the eve of battle. There, Krishna makes it\nclear that action cannot be avoided; because inaction is also action; and that\nselfish actions, and attachment to their fruits, lead to entrapment. With\nrespect to this triumph of world literature and philosophy, the Bhagavad Gita,\none must acknowledge that in this sutra, Patanjali, in his usual crisp style,\nhas said exactly the same thing. Not even the superbly expressive style of the\nGita can eclipse Patanjali's intelligence in going straight to the heart of the\nmatter. How does a free man act, and yet remain free? This is the main thrust\nof the kaivalya pada. Here Patanjali evidently states that free action, beyond\ncausality, is his who acts without motive or desire - as if a kite were\nreleased in the sky, without a string to bring it back to earth. Actions of all\nHuman beings are called karmas. They arise from&nbsp;\nvasanas, which are deep, innate, in-built impressions or deep rooted\ntendencies or habits which prompt us to go in for different karmas, again and\nagain. They urge, drive, command and force us to go in and do this, or that\naction, though most of us fail to recognize them as the our inbuilt vasanas. These\nactions can be good, bad or a third type which is neither good nor bad. But, a\nYogi\u2019s actions do not arise from the old, innate vasanas (tendencies) or as\nkarma phalam. Therefore they are neither good nor bad, neither pure nor impure.\nYogi goes on doing his work - without seeking its fruit to himself. When the\nkarma phalam is not desired by him for himself, the karma itself does not bind\nhim as sin(paap) or good (Punya). While most aspirants have the habit of black,\nwhite, or mixed actions leading to consequences, a new habit can gradually be\nformed. Recall that one of the two foundation principles is vairagya, or\nnon-attachment . As non-attachment gradually comes through the many practices,\nthis habit of coloring with consequences lessens. Gradually, there are fewer\nconsequences or colorings (kleshas), which come from actions.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; An advanced yogi who has mastered the\ndhyana effortless linkage of the mind to a higher reality, may perform cultural\nactivities, just as others do but for him, these do not result in rewarding,\npenalizing nor fruitless results.&nbsp; What\nthen does the yogi gain from cultural activities?&nbsp;&nbsp; He gains absolutely nothing, because his\ndetachment allows the reactions to fall back into material nature without a\nclaimant.When the Yogi has attained to that state of perfection, the actions of\nthat man, and the Karma produced by those actions, will not bind him, because\nhe did not desire them. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.08- - - tatastadvipakanugunanam\nevabhivyaktirvasananam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">These three types of\nactions leave impressions which become manifest when conditions are favourable\nand ripe. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of the four kinds of\naction, the first three leave behind potential residues, which are accumulated\nas impressions in the memory. Memories generate desires, and the results of\ndesires in turn grow to be memories. They move together and form dormant\nimpressions, which, according to their maturity, either manifest immediately or\nremain dormant; to appear unexpectedly later in this life or in future lives. Desire\nis the propelling force, which stimulates the body and mind and strives for\nsatiation. Desires and their fulfilment bind consciousness to the threefold\nactions. Desire and memory compel the mind to act for their gratification,\ndetermining one's future class of birth, span of life, and the kinds of\nexperiences to be undergone. If the impressions are good, they create\nsituations favourable to spiritual life. Unfavourable impressions bind one to\nlust, anger, greed, infatuation, pride and envy, creating perturbations in the\nconsciousness. But even then, if one turns one's consciousness towards the seer\nby sincerely and deferentially following the eightfold path of yogic\ndiscipline, one's actions will no longer be of the threefold type, but of the\nfourth, which do not give rise to desire for fruits or rewards. This is the\nliteral meaning of 'Yogah karmasu kausalam', 'skill of yogic action'. Karma\n(action), the creation of its vasanas in our mind, and the vasanas propelling\nus into karma of a similar type that created the vasana \u2013 these go on occurring\nin our minds in cycles. This is a karmic cycle. Why do we do a particular type\nof good, bad or neutral type deed? Because, vasanas of the same type are\nholding our mind in their power and urging our mind to act in the same or\nsimilar manner again and again. When we again do a karma on their influence,\nthat karma again creates further vasanas relating to it, which join their\nsimilar vasanas already in our minds and strengthens the them. These\nstrengthened vasanas again propel us into similar deeds, which create similar\nvasanas again; which go out and join their predecessor vasanas again. Thus\nkarmic cycle goes on and on \u2013 until an awareness dawns on us. Those threefold\nactions result in latent impressions (vasanas) that will later arise to\nfruition only corresponding to those impressions. Impressions match the\nactions: Whether actions are white, black, or mixed, the resulting deep\nimpressions (vasana) will also be of a similar nature. They too will be white,\nblack, or mixed. When those deep impressions once again arise to the surface,\ndriving further actions, speech, and thoughts, those too will have similar\nleanings. They can be altered through sadhana (spiritual practices) and\ndeciding to follow different courses of actions. Of these [actions], only those\nvasanas (subconscious impressions) for which there are favorable conditions for\nproducing their fruits will manifest in a particular birth. Because the\ntendency of the mind to act on the basis of the five obstacles, such as\nmisapprehension, has not been erased, they will surface in the future to\nproduce their unpleasant consequences.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;\nEverything in the material creation works according to innate tendency,\nmanifesting according to time and place.&nbsp;\nSometimes it takes thousands of years before something can manifest or\nbe given any type of satisfaction. Desires can only manifest themselves in\nproper environments. Only those desires will come out for which the environment\nis fitted; the rest will remain stored up. In this life we have many&nbsp; godly desires, many human desires, many\nanimal desires. &nbsp;Only that Karma which is\nsuited to and fitted for the environments will come out. These proves that the\npower of environment is the great check to control even Karma itself.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.09- - - jatideshakalavyavahitanam\napyanantaryam smritisanskarayoh ekaroopatvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Life is a continuous\nprocess, even though it is demarcated by race, place and time. Due to the\nuninterrupted close relationship between memory and subliminal impressions, the\nfruits of actions remain intact from one life to the next, as if there were no\nseparation between births. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As per Sanatana Dharma\n, the law of karma functions uninterruptedly throughout successive lifetimes,\nthough each life is separated by rank, place and time. Desires and impressions\nare stored in the memory and link the behavioural patterns of previous lives\nwith present and future lives. The theory of karma, or the law of cause and\neffect, is explained to inspire the sadhaka which will release him from the\ndesires and results which are simply the accumulated actions of his previous\nlives. In the previous sutra, the common identity of latent habitual impressions\nand memories was pointed out. Memories and impressions are interrelated,\ninterconnected, interwoven. They act as stimuli in the present life. Even if\nprevious lives are divided by social condition, status, time and place, the\noneness of memory and impression flashes consciously, subconsciously or\nunconsciously and moulds the pattern of the present life. For instance, if a\nman's life has taken shape after undergoing many lives in the form of other\nspecies, memory and impressions at once connect the past to the present life\neven though the interval between them may be a long one. One can thus conclude\nthat the seed of future lives is planted in the present life, 'As you sow, so\nshall you reap: we are responsible in this life for moulding our future lives'.\nThe theory of karma, far from being a fatalistic theory of 'predestination', as\nmany people misunderstand it to be, serves to make one aware of his/her\nresponsibilities and one's power to affect the future course of one's life. It\nacts as a guide, inspiring one to perform virtuous actions which will gradually\nlead one towards the expertise of performing desireless actions. Theory of\nKarma kicks in only when the soul enters a human body. Once a soul enters a conscious\nhuman body it does not revert back into an animal in the next birth. Our\nvasanas do not leave us merely because we go to a different place; stay in a\ndifferent period or even become a living being of a different type. &nbsp;Our changing a residence from one place to\nanother is not going to remove our innate habits or vasanas. When we grow older\nand older, the time changes, but our vasanas become stronger, because, vasanas\nresult in karma, which further creates vasanas, which results in strengthening\nthe already existing vasanas in us. Even if we die and take re-birth in a\ndifferent human race, our vasanas come along with us \u2013 as if they are a\ncontinuity. We carry them along wherever we go. &nbsp;Soul samskaras don\u2019t die, even when we do. Since\nmemory (smriti) and the deep habit patterns (samskaras) are the same in\nappearance, there is an unbroken continuity in the playing out of those traits,\neven though there might be a gap in location, time, or state of life. Memory\nand predisposition are in alignment: Because the process of remembering\n(smriti) and the underlying predispositions (samskaras) are in alignment, when\nthe right opportunities arise, those two, once again, begin to play out in the\nactions in the external world. It is as if there was no break, no gap, although\nthere was. You simply pick up where you left off. Feeling of doing something\nbefore: It is very common for people to have deja vu experiences, where it\nseems like something is familiar, some place, people, circumstance, or activity.\nOne of the ways this can happen is this process of memory and samskara\nmatching, and of continuity in the playing out of the actions (karmas). The\ncircumstances might not literally be the same, but the process of unfolding\nkarma is unbroken in the way described here, thus leading quite naturally to\nthe feeling of familiarity. : Imagine that you are working on some project at\nyour job, but that it is interrupted by a vacation of a few weeks. When you\nreturn to work, you pick up where you left off. Two things were there. First,\nyou had memory (smriti) of what you were doing, and second, you had a driving\nforce (samskara) in you to complete the project. Both of these were similar to\none another. Although there was a gap in time (the vacation), the project went\non when you returned, just as if you had not been away. &nbsp;Imagine that you died and were reborn in a new\nbody, at some future time, and in a different place. You would have memories,\nthough possibly vague or unconscious, and you would have latent predispositions.\nAlthough desires are separated from their fulfillments by class, space and\ntime, they have an uninterrupted relationship because the impressions [of\ndesires] and memories of them are identical. Life is a continuous process, even\nthough it is demarcated by race, place and time. Due to the uninterrupted close\nrelationship between memory and subliminal impressions, the fruits of actions\nremain intact from one life to the next, as if there were no separation between\nbirths. Memory and latent impressions are strongly linked. This link remains\neven if there is an interval of time, place, or context between similar\nactions. Acquired soul samskaras become the cause of action in that body. &nbsp;Deep rooted phobias can only be amputated by\npast life regression. &nbsp;There is NO modern\nmedicine for this.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.10- - - tasam\nanaditvam chashisho nityatvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">These impressions,\nmemories and desires have existed eternally, as the desire to live is eternal. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as the universe is\neternal, so are impressions and desires. They have existed from the distant\npast, beyond anybody's memory. For one whose seeds of blemishes are eliminated,\nand whose desires have come to an end, the turmoils of the universe appear to\nhave come to an end. Nobody knows the timeless, primordial, absolute One, or\nwhen the world came into existence. Both purusa and prakrti, spirit and nature,\nexisted before man appeared. When creation took place, man was empowered with\nconsciousness, intelligence, mind, senses of perception, organs of action and\nbody. At the same time the characteristics or qualities (gunas) of nature,\nillumination (sattva), action (rajas) and inertia (lamas) entered man's body.\nSet on the wheel of time with the spokes of the gunas of nature, man began to\nfunction in conformity with these three fundamental, intermingling qualities.\nThough born with an unpolluted heart, he gradually became caught in the snare\nof nature and fell victim to the polarities of pleasure and pain, good and\nevil, love and hatred, the permanent and transient. That is how desires\n(vasana) and imprints (samskara) rooted themselves in man's life, and why this\nsutra says that desires have existed from time immemorial. Caught in these\nreverses, man felt the need of a personal divinity, unaffected by afflictions,\nuntouched by actions and reactions, and free from the experience of joy and\nsorrow. This led to a search for the highest ideal embodied in purusa, or God.\nThrough this search arrived culture, and finally civilization. Man learned to\ndifferentiate between good and evil, virtue and vice, and what is moral and\nimmoral. That is how yoga was discovered. Through yoga sadhana, the desires\nthat have existed since the beginning of time are eliminated so that kaivalya\ncan be experienced. In II.12, Patanjali explained that the causes of actions\nare hidden, accumulated impressions of one's past deeds. In this chapter he\nspeaks of pure actions, which collect and store no imprints. The essential\nnature of citta is tranquillity - santa citta. When the sadhaka does not permit\nthought-waves to arise (vyutthana citta), naturally there is no need for their\nrestraint, nirodha citta. As both are filtered by santa citta, the sadhaka\nresides in this quiet state and performs his duties. His actions are pure, and\ntheir outcome too will be pure.. Due to ignorance, joy and sorrow occur and\ndeepen, according to one's surroundings. If allowed free rein, they agitate the\nserene state of consciousness and the gates of kaivalya may remain closed\nforever. But one can sever the links of desires by developing the mind through\nthe grace of yoga. As long as one practices yoga, one is free from desire.\nDedicated, life-long practice of yoga stops the wheel of desires, so that one\nlives in the state of poise and peace. Desires started is us \u2013 when we started\nour life journey. They are born along with us. It emanates from our will to\nlive. Patanjali says that desires and their innate vasanas have no beginning. &nbsp;But, he has not said that they do not have an end.\nIf we recognize the nature and consequences of desire, vasanas, and the\nconsequent karmas and karmaphalam \u2013 Patanjali shows us the way out of their\ncycle. Samadhi is essentially intended to end this cycle. There is no beginning\nto the process of these deep habit patterns (samskaras), due to the eternal\nnature of the will to live. &nbsp;The will to\nlive is the primordial out-flowing of the urge to manifest. This eternal\nprocess of cause and effect means that there is also no beginning to the\nprocess of deep habit patterns (samskaras) springing forth into thoughts and\nactions, and their subsequent creation of memories and impressions . The\ncycling process of deep impressions, actions, consequences, and storage of\nmemories is without beginning. Self-realization is not from regression\nanalysis: Therefore, the approach to Self-realization is other than tracing\nback our individual personality development in some linear regression of cause\npreceding effect. In some approaches of psychological examination this might be\na valid method, but not in the case of seeking enlightenment. In spiritual\nmatters, it ultimately provides little fruit to try to figure out how we got to\nour present circumstances. It is far better to seek the direct experience of\nthe eternal core of our being, regardless of the nature of the wrappings of\nfalse identities. With the removal of obstacles, that realization naturally\nflows. Those memories and impressions are primeval, without a beginning, hope\nand desire energies are eternal as well. When a yogi sees that the hope and\ndesire energy is eternal, he makes a decision to let it be and to detach\nhimself from the urges.&nbsp; He must, by all\nmeans, get himself separated from the mento-emotional force or remain a victim\nof it.&nbsp; The memories and the\ncircumstance-forming impressions will be there for all eternity.&nbsp;&nbsp; A yogin has no choice but to extract his\nexistence from the realm of it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red;\"><br /></span></b><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.11- - - hetufalashrayalambanaih\nsangrihitatvad esham abhave tadabhavah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Impressions and desires\nare bound together by their dependence upon cause and effect. In the absence of\nthe latter, the former too ceases to function. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lack of understanding -\navidya, gives rise to suffering, which in turn create desires. This causes the endless\ncycle of rebirths. &nbsp;The accumulated\nimpressions of memory are without beginning, but have a definite end, provided\nthe individual becomes cultured and discerning. When the formation of desire is\nkept in suspension, the cycle of rebirths come to an end. The sight of an\nobject creates motivation, which acts as a springboard for desire. Desire\nnurtures motive, and motive ignites action aimed at fulfillment of the desire.\nThis nourishes further desires, which then lodge permanently in the seat of the\nconsciousness, binding the soul forever. Through regular, deferential practice\nof yoga, and the use of discriminative intelligence, this web of object,\nmotivation, desire and reward is made to fade away. Then the pairs of opposites\n- vice and virtue, pain and pleasure, aversion and attachment - gradually\nweaken and then disappear. This brings sensitivity and refinement to the\nconsciousness, which now averts desires and thoughts of reward, and directs its\nattention towards the exploration of the seer. In this sutra, Patanjali is\nbriefly making us understand the nature of our desires. At one level, Desire is\nthe cause and the effort we make to satisfy the same is its effect. But, desire\nitself is an effect, for which, the cause is in the chitta , the vasanas of\npast actions&nbsp; which are stored in Chitta\nas Subtle samskaras, which are waiting to convert into desires and seek their\nsatisfaction. Every action to satisfy a desire again leaves its imprint on the\nChitta. This is called a vasana. It gets stored in Chitta as very subtle\nimpressions called Samskaras. Sanskaras are like our habits. But, they are\ndeeper imprints on the Chitta and may even be inherited from a previous birth. They\nare constantly driving us into actions for desire-satisfaction. The causes are\nthese samskaras and the effects are the efforts that we are driven into, for\ntheir satisfaction. Every desire has to rest on the support of an Indriya and\nan external object. Thus, for each desire, there is an external object, and an\nindriya which supports the whole action to satisfy the desire, a desire which\nis the effect and a samskara in the Chitta which is the cause. We cannot remove\nthe effects straightaway, when the causes are in tact in us. We must tackle the\ncauses, the Samskaras and vasanas in us. We must also restrain the Indriyas\nfrom the external objects. Unless all four corners of the desire are tackled,\nthere is no way to get rid of the cycle of desires. When we start with the\ncauses, and look at all four pillars, and ensure their disappearance, desires\nautomatically disappear. This does not mean indriyas and external objects will\nhave to disappear. Their non-contact with each other is simple enough to break\nthe cycle. Since the impressions &nbsp;are\nheld together by cause, motive, substratum, and object, they disappear when\nthose deep impressions disappear. Four parts interact: All of our false\nidentities, attractions, aversions, or fears exist along with an interplay of\nthe process between four parts. These four hold together the deep impressions\nor samskaras described in the last two sutras . When these four are dissolved,\nthe samskaras also dissolve. The four parts holding together the samskaras are:\nCause: One thought leads to another. An action brings a consequence. The\nconsequence gets stored in memory. It later gets triggered into more active\nthoughts and actions. On goes the cycle, over and over. This is the process of\ncausation. Motive: Another part of the process, whether you conceptualize this\nin subtle ways, or gross ways, such as brain neurons, is that actions, speech,\nand thoughts come from a motivating process. This is somewhat self-evident; we\nare all aware of this. Substratum: In all of these cases, however you may\nspecifically conceptualize it, there is the fact that every action, speech, or\nthought has some other root entity or process. Again, with a bit of reflection,\nthis is also self evident. Object: In all of these false identities,\nattractions, aversions, or fears there are also objects, always, whether they\nare subtle objects of the mind, or their related gross objects of the external\nworld. They are there, and the interplay with cause, motive, and substratum. : What\nwould then happen to those deep impressions, if the four part chain of cause,\nmotive, substratum, and object were broken? Then, the deep impressions would\nalso cease to be repeatedly reinforced, which is what usually happens in the\ncycle of actions, consequences, actions, consequences, etc.. Then comes\nSelf-realization: When all of that is set aside, even for a short time, the\ntrue Self comes shining through . The impressions being held together by cause,\neffect, basis, and support, they disappear with the dissappearance of these\nfour. Our subconscious tendencies depend upon cause and effect. They have their\nbasis in the mind, and they are stimulated by the sense-objects. If all these\nare removed, the tendencies are destroyed. These tendencies are both maintained\nand sustained by misapprehensions, external stimuli, attachment to the fruits\nof actions, and the quality of mind that promotes hyperactivity. Reduction of\nthese automatically makes the undesirable impressions ineffective.&nbsp; For a yogi, his involvement is the supportive\nelement which makes the subtle material nature exist for him and engage him or\nuse his consciousness.&nbsp; Thus if he\ndetaches himself the supportive element being removed, material nature no\nlonger affects him.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.12- - - atitanagatan\nsvaroopatostyadhvabhedad dharmanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The existence of the\npast and the future is as real as that of the present. As moments roll into\nmovements which have yet to appear as the future, the quality of knowledge in\none's intellect and consciousness is affected. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The understanding of\ntime liberates one from bondage. Time is a system revealing the sequential\nrelation that one event has to succeed another and another and so on, as past,\npresent, or future. Time is regarded as an indefinite continuous duration,\nwherein events follow one another. &nbsp;The\npast and future are as real as the present. The orderly rhythmic procession of\nmoments (ksana cakra) into movements is the wheel of time (kala cakra). Its\nexistence is real and eternal. &nbsp;The\npresent may fade into the past, or manifest clearly at a future time. Due to\nthe play of the gums of nature, conditions change, raising the illusion that\ntime has changed. &nbsp;Past and future are\nwoven into the present, though they appear different due to the movement of\nmoments. &nbsp;Desire nurtures action aimed at\nits gratification. The interlude between desire, action and fulfillment\ninvolves time, which manifests as past, present and future. True understanding\nof motivation and the movement of moments release a yogi from the loop of\nbondage. &nbsp;Moment is changeless and\neternal. Moments flow into movements eternally and are measurable as past,\npresent and future. This measurable time is finite, when contrasted with\neternity. &nbsp;The negative effects of time\nare intellectual (lack of spiritual knowledge, avidya, and pride, asmita);\nemotional (attachment to pleasure, raga, and aversion to pain, dvesa); and\ninstinctive (the desire to cling to life, abhini-Qesa). Time's positive effect\nis the attainment of knowledge. The experience of the past supports the\npresent, and progress in the present builds a sound foundation for the future.\nOne uses the past as a guide to develop discriminative power, alertness and\nawareness, which smoothens the path for Self-Realisation. The yogi who studies\nin depth this unique rotation of time, stays detached from the movement of\nmoments; he rests in the present. Thus he becomes clear of head, clean of\nheart, and free from time, which binds consciousness. When the concurrence\nbetween the movement of moments and consciousness terminates, freedom and\nbeatitude - kaivalya, are experienced. Human concept of time is not based on\nreality, but merely on the perception of the senses and the mind, whose\ncapabilities are limited. In reality, the whole of past exists even now, in\nthis very moment, but, it is hidden from human perception by being placed in a\ndifferent plane, which is unavailable to human eye and mind. Likewise, the\nwhole of future too, is available right now, in this moment. This is also\nhidden from eye and mind, by being placed in a different plane, unavailable to\nus. Past and future have different characteristics compared to his moment. The\npower to perceive those characteristics is not available to ordinary human\nmind. But, certainly, these are not beyond the Yogi\u2019s power of perception. We\nlive in the present. But, as we all know, our mind is constantly oscillating\nbetween the past and future. In fact, it is very difficult to keep the mind in\nthis moment. The Yogi\u2019s effort is not to go into the past or into the future,\nbut, to keep the mind in the here and now. But, Patanjali affirms that past and\npresent are available in the present moment itself \u2013 in different planes, due\nto their different characteristics. It is not that past just vanishes away\ntotally, nor that future comes into our life from nothingness.&nbsp; They are always available but come into our\nconsciousness as the present moment only and then go back into their planes. Past\nand future are in the here and now: All of the characteristics, forms,\nmemories, deep impressions, etc., exist in the here and now, whether in active\nor potential forms. The appearance of past and future comes from the condition,\npath, or order in which they are sequenced. &nbsp;The existence of the past and the future is as\nreal as that of the present. As moments roll into movements which have yet to\nappear as the future, the quality of knowledge in one's intellect and\nconsciousness is affected. &nbsp;Time is not\nan illusion.&nbsp; It is real in that\nsense.&nbsp; Because of definite\ncharacteristics, there is a certain course which time takes from the past into\nthe present and into the yet-emerging future.&nbsp;\nThe inherent characteristics (dharmanam) from the past mold the\nfuture.&nbsp; The changes which come about in\nthe present are stockpiled by time as the basis for slight or major differences\nwhich are to come.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.13- - - te\nvyaktasookshma gunatmanah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The three phases of\ntime intermingle rhythmically and interweave with the qualities of nature. They\nchange the composition of nature's properties into gross and subtle. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Desires, actions and\nrewards are not only intertwined with the cycle of time, but are also composed\nand hidden according to the rhythmic movement of sattva, rajas and tamas. They\nmay manifest and be brought to the surface, or remain hidden and rise up later.\nBound to the wheel of time by the gunas, man started to form ideas, fuelled by\ndesires in the fire of consciousness. Then, through past actions and\nexperiences, he began to mould his life in order to gain freedom from\ndualities. This involved time, which has no beginning or end, is simply a\nsuccession of moments. Though each moment is eternal and real in its continuous\nflow, it changes into movement. To be free from the cycles of cause and effect,\nman has to mould his behaviour from moment to moment. The cause is subtle but\nthe effect is felt. The effects of one's actions of yesterday are the cause of\ntoday; and the experience of one's actions today becomes the seed of the\nactions tomorrow. All actions revolve around time and the qualities of nature. A\nyogi has learned to weaken ignorance and increase the light of knowledge. He\nhas moved from ignorance to knowledge, and darkness to light, from death to\nimmortality. He alone knows how to live freely, unaffected by the onslaughts of\nnature. This is kaivalya. When the whole Universe is composed of the three\nGunas, naturally, the past, present, and future also are composed of the same\nthree gunas. There is nothing in life which is not connected with the three\nGunas. In every life form, we can see all the three Gunas but in different\nproportions . Satva Guna represented by Stability can be seen in the\nnon-changeability and permanence of the past.&nbsp;\nRajoguna represented by action can be seen the present. All action\nhappens only in the present. No action can take place in the past or future.\nBut, the present is a continuity in itself and we do know it. That is why all\naction can and does occur in the present only. Tamoguna represented by inertia\ncan be seen in the future. The future never comes! It is always away. It is\nnever experience-able directly. It is always in seed form. The Tree always\nbelongs to the present.&nbsp; In our\nknowledge, the present always recedes into the past, even as future drives\nitself into the present constantly.&nbsp; Past\nhad manifested earlier. Present is now manifest. Future remains un-manifest. In\nall the three cases, all the three of them are composed of the three Gunas\nonly. When there is perfect equilibrium between the three gunas, there is no\nmanifestation of the universe. It is only when there are fluctuations or\nmodifications (vikaras or vikritis) among them that there begins to be\nmanifestation.&nbsp; The three phases of time\nintermingle rhythmically and interweave with the qualities of nature. They\nchange the composition of nature's properties into gross and subtle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.14- - - parinamaikatvad\nvastutattvam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Unity in the mutation\nof time caused by the abiding qualities of nature, sattva, rajas and tamas\ncauses modifications in objects, but their unique essence, or reality, does not\nchange. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As there is a\nharmonious alteration between sattva, rajas and tamas (prakasa, kriya and\nsthiti), both in nature and in the individual self, so there are differences in\nthe way one perceives objects. According to the predominating gunas in one's\nintelligence, an object is perceived differently, although its essence remains\nthe same. The yogi penetrates the harmonious combination of nature with its\ngunas, clearly understands their mutations, and stays detached from them. This\nstudy helps him to remain in the essence of his object of contemplation, which\nis not bound by time or qualities of nature. This object is the unchangeable\nseer, or the soul. The seer is not bound by time, whereas mind is. Due to one's\naccumulated desires and impressions, one's ways of thinking, seeing and feeling\nchange. Truth is One, and one must experience it in its real essence, without\ndistinctions. If it seems to fluctuate, that is because one's intelligence and\nperception fluctuates, and this prevents one from seeing the essential truth.\nIf intelligence and consciousness are filtered and refined, both subject and\nobject retain and reflect their real essence. When Patanjali says that\ndualities disappear when asanas are performed perfectly (11.48), he is\nexplaining that the essence of an object does not vary - subject and object\nmerge into one, so distinctions between them do not arise. Each object\nexternally appears to be a single unit to our perception. But, the object is a\nmix of all the three Gunas. In fact, all objects, all living beings are formed\nby the different combinations of the three Gunas, which mix in any number of\nproportions. The three gunas (4.13) all manifest together, and the result is\nthe appearance of a single object, rather than seeing the parts which make up\nthe whole. Only the composite is seen, not the three components. Since the\ngunas work together within every change of form and expression, there is a\nunity in all things. The characteristics of an object appear as a single unit,\nas they manifested uniformly from the underlying elements. The actual\ncomposition of an object is based on the uniqueness of the transformation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.15- - - vastusamye\nchittabhedat tayorvibhaktah panthah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Due to the variance in\nthe quality of mind-content, each person may view the same object differently,\naccording to his own way of thinking. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The object (nature or\nprakrti) is as real as the subject (purusa), but though the substance of nature\nor object remains the same, the perceptions of it vary according to the\ndifference in the development of each person's consciousness. Here,\nconsciousness is the perceiver and the object perceived becomes the object to\nbe known. On account of the wheel of time, substance and qualities of nature\nand consciousness as perceiver develops differently in each individual. Though\ndifferent perceivers see an object in different fashions, yet it remains the\nsame. For instance, the same man or woman is a pleasure to a beloved or a lover\nand a pain to a rival. He or she may be an object of indifference to an ascetic\nand of no interest to a renunciate. Thus, the object is the same, the perceiver\nsees in the light of the interplay of the various gunas. When the yogi realises\nthat the perceiver in the form of consciousness is not the real perceiver but\nan instrument of its lord - the seer or purusa - it begins to discard its\nfluctuations and also its outer form, ego, so as to merge into a single\nun-vacillating mind. This allows the single mind to unite in the seer, and the\nseer to shine forth in the light of the soul. This is atmo jnana, leading to\nBrahma jnana. Objects are existing independent of the minds that perceive them.\nBut, our perception of these objects depends entirely on our different\nmindsets. Each person perceiving the same object, perceives it differently&nbsp; because their mindsets have grown in\ndifferent circumstances with differing perceptional abilities. A doctor, an\nartist and a lover do not see the same person in the same way. Doctor sees the\nphysical health and ill-health aspects, artist sees the beauty of the person\nfrom his view-point and the lover\u2019s eyes can\u2019t see anything ugly in the person.\nWe often wonder why we have so many views on the same incident. A murder has\nhappened. Someone tries to justify it as an accident. Someone sympathizes with\nthe murderer. Someone looks at the murdered person\u2019s body with mere curiosity.\nSomeone turns his face away from the dead body.&nbsp;\nBut, the murdered person\u2019s wife and kith and kin fall on the body and\nweep profusely and demand justice. The brother of the murdered person\u2019s wife\nmay pick up a knife himself and go after the murderers. Perceptions and\nresponses differ from mindset to mindset \u2013 due to the division of the ways of\nperception. We are all different in our mindsets. We all differ in our\nperceptions. But, external objects, happenings are same. Patanjali is offering\nus a psychological explanation of why the turmoil and differences in the world.\nDue to the variance in the quality of mind-content, each person may view the\nsame object differently, according to his own way of thinking.&nbsp;&nbsp; The characteristics of an object appear\ndifferently, depending upon the different mental states of the observer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.16- - - na cha eka\nchitta tantram ched vastu tat pramanakam tada kim syat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">An object exists\nindependent of its cognisance by any one consciousness. What happens to it when\nthat consciousness is not there to perceive it? </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The essence of an\nobject is not dependent upon one's mind or consciousness. If the mind or\nconsciousness does not recognise the object, it means that mind or\nconsciousness does not see, or that the object does not stimulate the seer. But\nthis does not mean that the object does not exist. As prakrti is as real and\neternal as purusa, so are object and subject. Due to unripe intelligence and\ndifferences in the development of consciousness, each individual perceives\nobjects according to his own intellectual 'wavelength', although their essence\ndoes not change. When a yogi reaches perfection in his sadhana, intelligence\nand consciousness touch the supreme knowledge - he becomes a fulfilled yogi,\nand remains merely a detached witness of objects. The mind ignites stimuli in\nthe senses of perception, or vice versa, and the organs of action participate,\nso that the mind can experience objects. These experiences are imprinted\naccording to the development of the mind, and in turn create impressions on the\nconsciousness. If an object does not stir the mind, it remains unperceived by\nthe mind or the mind fails to grasp it. When the mind is released from the play\nof the gunas, it perceives objects in their true reality, and remains free from\nimpressions. Its contact with perceived objects is cut off. Then mind and soul\nbecome one, and are one with the essence of all objects. The objects themselves\nare independent of the perceiving minds. Whether any mindset perceives it or\nnot is immaterial for the object. Reality exists independent of our perception.\n&nbsp;Our perceptions of reality are hugely\ndifferent from reality and are based on our limited, differing perceptual\ncapabilities. An object exists independent of its cognizance by any one\nconsciousness. &nbsp;Yoga focuses on the\npractical path of going beyond the levels of reality, so as to experience the\neternal center.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.17- - - tad uparaga\napeksitvat chittasya vastu jnata ajnatam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">An object remains known\nor unknown according to the conditioning or expectation of the consciousness. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consciousness is not\nthe seer, but an instrument of the seer. A conditioned mind can never perceive\nan object correctly. If the mind sees the object without expectation, it\nremains free. An object is understood and known according to the expectation of\nthe mind, or remains unrecognized, owing to the absence of reflection. When the\nobject attracts the mind, contact and reflection begin. This gives rise to\nknowledge. If the mind fails to come in contact with the object, it does not\nperceive it and the object remains unknown. If consciousness is conditioned or\ncoloured (vrttis and Mesas - 1.6 and 11.6), knowledge of the object also\nbecomes coloured. When the consciousness reflects on the object without\ncondition, taint or expectation, its real essence is known. Likewise, if the\nconsciousness reflects on the essence of the seer without conditioning, bias,\nor prejudice, the mind becomes enlightened. It knows that it is not itself the\nseer, but only an instrument of the seer. The un-enlightened mistake mind and\nconsciousness for the seer. Objects exist independent of the mind. But, whether\nwe will know them or not depends upon whether we perceive them or not \u2013 and\nwhen we perceive them, how we perceive them. Our perceptions are coloured. They\nare conditioned by many, many factors connected with our upbringing and\nprofessions. Our minds never remain uncoloured. A yogi looks at every woman as\na mother. A sexist may look at every woman as a sex object. Every human being\u2019s\nperceptions are coloured and conditioned by their background. Whether we will\nknow the object itself, and how much of it\u2019s reality we will know,&nbsp; depends on these factors. Objects are either\nknown or not known according to the way in which the coloring of that object\nfalls on the coloring of the mind observing it. Objects are either known or not\nknown according to the way in which the coloring of that object falls on the\ncoloring of the mind observing it. In other words, it is the coloring of one's\nown mind that determines perception. Reduce coloring to see clearly: In the\nprevious section (4.13-4.14) the very subtle building blocks (gunas) of the\nsubconscious mental impressions are dealt with. Even these most subtle\nelements, like the more surface thought patterns, are subject to the same\nprinciple and practice of uncoloring (aklishta) the colored (klishta) thought\npatterns. This process of uncoloring is a core principle of the science of Yoga.\nWhether an object is perceived or not depends on its accessibility as well as\nthe individual's motivation. Objects are either known or not known according to\nthe way in which the coloring of that object falls on the coloring of the mind\nobserving it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.18- - - &nbsp;sada jnatashchittavrittayastatprabhoh purushasyaparinamitvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Purusa is ever\nilluminative and changeless. Being constant and master of the mind, he always\nknows the moods and modes of consciousness. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Lord of\nconsciousness is the seer. He is changeless, constant, and never alters or\nstumbles. In deep sleep, consciousness forgets itself. It is purusa, as a\nwitness which reminds the mind of sleep after waking. This designates that\npurusa is ever alert and aware (sada jnata). Purusa's alertness will be known\nto the sadhaka only when consciousness is purified and liberated from rising\nthoughts and their restraints. Then the sadhaka, the seeker, becomes the seer. The\nseer knows his consciousness and its branchings. He is the seed and root, and\nconsciousness is the seedling. Its stem is the 'I' consciousness (asmita),\nwhich branches forth as ego, intelligence and mind. The seer, being the seed\nand root of consciousness, observes the changes and transformations taking\nplace within it. The mind is never constant. It is ever-changing.&nbsp; Our thoughts, ideas, perceptions are always\nchanging. These are the modifications of our mind. But, behind these\nmodifications, there is an unchanging PURUSHA, the pure consciousness, who is\nthe watcher of all these modifications. The Purusha is the constant witness of\nthe mind and its modifications. The Purusha is superior to and is the master of\nthe Chitta.&nbsp; In other words, always two\nthings are happening simultaneously in us. At one level, within the mind is a\nconstant stream of ever-changing thoughts, emotions, ideas, desires and so on.\nBehind all this changes in the mind \u2013 there is a witnessing soul \u2013 the Purusha,\nwho is changeless&nbsp; and permanent. It is\nonly against this unchanging background of the Purusha, that all changes can\noccur in the mind. This unchanging Purusha is the lord, the pure consciousness,\nthe real ruler of the mind-stuff. And, he does it merely by witnessing and not\nparticipating. The activities of the mind are always known by the pure\nconsciousness, because that pure consciousness is superior to, support of, and\nmaster over the mind. The activities of the mind are always known by the pure\nconsciousness, because that pure consciousness is superior to, support of, and\nmaster over the mind. Purusa is ever illuminative and changeless. Being\nconstant and master of the mind, he always knows the moods and modes of\nconsciousness. Because the Atman, the Lord of the mind, is unchangeable, the\nmind's fluctuations are always known to it.&nbsp;\nThe activities of the mind are always known by the pure consciousness,\nbecause that pure consciousness is superior to, support of, and master over the\nmind.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.19- - - &nbsp;na tat svabhasandrishyatvat</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Consciousness cannot\nillumine itself, because it is a knowable object. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consciousness can be\nseen as an object. It is knowable and perceptible. It is not self-illuminative\nlike the seer. Consciousness being the seedling of the seer, its growth and\nluminosity depends upon the seed - the light of the seer. Its own light is like\nthat of the moon, which is reflected light from the sun. The seer represents\nthe sun, and consciousness the moon. As a child feels strong and secure in the\npresence of its parents, consciousness, the child of the seer, draws its\nstrength from the seer. Consciousness, like the senses of perception, can\ngenerally see an object but not its own form. For an average person, the eyes\npose as the seer when comprehending worldly objects. For an intellectual\nperson, the eyes become the seen, and the mind the seer. For an enlightened\nperson, mind and intelligence become objects for the consciousness. But for the\nwise seer, consciousness itself becomes the object perceived. The seer can be\nsubject and object at the same time; consciousness cannot. It may hence be\ndeduced that consciousness has no light of its own. When the borrowed light of\nconsciousness is drawn back to its source, the seer, or soul, glows brilliantly.\nThe Purusha remains the witness and perceives everything through the mind and\nthe mind itself. This being so, the mind is not the power that actually\nperceives. This power lies with the Purusha. Purusha\u2019s power only reflects\nthrough the mind .Mind is not self-illuminating, as it is the object of\nknowledge and perception by the pure consciousness. Mind is made of the three\ngunas , and is not, in itself, consciousness. Rather, consciousness (purusha)\noperates through the mind. When the consciousness (purusha) operates through\nthe mind, it is also witness of the mind. The instrument of thinking itself is\nbeing seen and transcended in the pursuit of the direct experience of pure\nconsciousness.&nbsp; The mind is a part of\nwhat is perceived and has no power of its own to perceive. The Purusa alone is\nself-luminous, and gives its light to everything.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.20- - - &nbsp;ekasamaye chobhayanavadharannam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Consciousness cannot\napprehend both the seer and itself at the same time. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It cannot comprehend\nsubject-object, observer-observed, or actor-witness at the same time, whereas\nthe seer can. Day and night cannot exist simultaneously. In the same way,\nrestlessness and restfulness cannot co-exist in absolute juxtaposition. In\nbetween night and day there is dawn. Likewise, there is space between the flow\nof restlessness, cittavritti or cittavahini, and restfulness, prasanta vritti\nor prasanta vahini. In between these two rivers of restlessness and\nrestfulness, and underneath them, flows the concealed invisible secret river -\nthe river of the soul. This is dawn, or the sudden arrival of enlightenment. For\na yogi, restlessness is the night and restfulness is the day. In between, there\nis a third state which is neither day nor night, but dawn. It is the dispersion\nof consciousness, in which the rivers of restlessness and restfulness unite in\nthe seat of absolute consciousness. When the water of a lake is tranquil, the\nreflection of the moon on its surface is crystal clear. Similarly, when the\nlake of consciousness is serene, consciousness disperses itself. This is known\nas a glimpse, or a reflection of the soul. The seer, being constant and\nunchangeable, can perceive the fluctuations as well as the serenity of\nconsciousness. If consciousness itself were self-luminous, it too could be the\nknower and the knowable. As it does not possess the power to be both, a wise\nyogi disciplines it, so that he may be alive to the light of the soul. &nbsp;It is stated in the Bhagavad Gita (11.69) 'One\nwho is self-controlled is awake when it appears night to all other beings, and\nwhat appears to him as night keeps others awake'. A yogic sadhaka thus realises\nthat when consciousness is active, the seer is asleep and when the seer is\nawake, it is night to the consciousness. &nbsp;Similarly, in the Hatha Yoga Pradipika, the\nword ha is used to indicate the seer as the 'sun', which never fades, whereas\ntha represents consciousness as the 'moon', which eternally waxes and wanes. We\nknow that mind itself can be cognized. But, the whole cognition process happens\nonly through the mind. It must be clear to us that cognition of the mind and\ncognition of the external matters and objects cannot happen simultaneously\nthrough the same mind itself. Nor can both the mind and the illuminating\nprocess be cognized simultaneously. Awareness of mind and witness don't\ncoexist: It is not possible to be aware of an object in the mind field at the\nsame time there is awareness of one's true nature as the illuminator of the\nmind. It cannot execute the focus of both at the same time. If the mind were\nself-luminous it would be able to cognize everything at the same time, which it\ncannot. &nbsp;If the mind were self-luminous\nthere would be no limit to the impressions it could receive. The Purusa can\ncognise all in one moment; therefore the Purusa is self-luminous, and the mind\nis not.&nbsp; Consciousness cannot comprehend\nboth the seer and itself at the same time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">4.21- - - &nbsp;chittantaradrishye buddhibuddheratiprasanggah smritisankarashcha</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">If consciousness were\nmanifold in one's being, each cognising the other, the intelligence too would\nbe manifold, so the projections of mind would be many, each having its own\nmemory. <o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plurality of\nconsciousness would result in lack of understanding between one mind and\nanother, leading to utter confusion and madness. Patanjali thus concludes that\nconsciousness is one and cannot be many. &nbsp;As a tree has numerous branches, all connected\nto the trunk, similarly, the various wavelengths of thoughts are connected to a\nsingle consciousness. This consciousness remains unadulterated and divine at\nits source in the spiritual heart. When it branches from the source towards the\nhead, it is called created consciousness - nirmita citta, which, being fresh,\nis inexpert and uncultured. The moment it comes into contact with objects, it\nbecomes tainted, creating moods in the thought-waves. These moods are the five\nfluctuations (vntis) and five afflictions (klesas) . Moods should not be\nmistaken for a plurality of minds. The mind stays the same, but moods generate\nan illusion of several minds. If the minds were really many, then each would\nhave its own memory and intelligence. This becomes outrageous. Just as a room\nfitted with mirrors baffles the onlooker, similarly, the idea of many minds\ncauses confusion and irrationality. The practice of yoga disciplines and\ncultures the consciousness of the head, by which it perfects the art of\nanalysis (savitarka), judges precisely (savicara), experiences unalloyed bliss\n(ananda), becomes auspicious (sasmi-ta) and moves towards mature intelligence\n(consciousness of the heart) and unalloyed wisdom (rtambhara prajna). &nbsp;If one mind were illumined by another, as its\nmaster, then there would be an endless and absurd progression of cognitions, as\nwell as confusion. The Yogi seeks only pure consciousness: Since the mind is\nnot self-illuminating, and there is not endless chain of minds, the Yogi seeks\nonly to have the direct experience of the pure consciousness or purusha .
